one could have talked to these killers

correspondents reflect on their
interactions and experiences covering
Nelson Mandela
I watched nails
I got off a plane in 2000 Russia
Tanzania he was there to broker peace in
Burundi which had been at war for quite
some time it was a terrible war 200,000
people were killed I had been very
excited to see him I owe it always
admired him but what I saw was a little
disappointing that mean to me he was 81
then he was you know really showing his
age he seemed to sort of weak and tired
when you ask questions he didn't they
weren't very sharp I thought to myself
you know I wish I'd seen him before
then he went into the convention room
and sat in front of these very same
people who had killed these 200,000
people and he lectured them like they
were school children the atmosphere
suddenly changed to absolute electricity
I I don't want to get this wrong so I
brought what he said he asked how these
men could could justify to the outside
world such slaughter he said when they
hear this they say Africans are still
barbarians though human beings could do
what they are doing please join the
modern world it's hard to overstate the
the power of these words I mean no one
could have talked to these killers like
that nobody in the entire world I think
and he got away with it and some of them
even said they felt bad to be scolded by
Mandela um that night I called my wife
my wife was pregnant and I said you know
I think I have a name for our child
and it's Nelson and he's 12 now I know
any thoughts about your name well to me
my name is just my name but as I got
older I realized what he really did and
how he was in jail for 27 years just to
prove a point
and I think it was really amazing
because he could have come out of jail
and really done anything and could have
has revenge on the people that
disrespected him and Africans but he
didn't and which is really amazing so
I'm really lucky that I've named after
such a hero
he met the world's press for the first
time in one of the most beautiful
gardens in South Africa the Archbishop
of Capetown hospital - - and there were
a thousand journalists there from all
over the world
Mandela sees himself beneath a Quinn
entry at a table and took questions
first question that really made an
impact on me was do you feel resentful
towards the white people of South Africa
for the 27 last years and how did he
respond to that he said how could he
feel resentful when his best friend
during his years of imprisonment was a
white water whom he named who had been
his friend throughout his time in prison
who had refused promotion and stayed
with him who eventually stood behind him
at his swearing-in and he said this man
for me represented the best of white
South Africa so how could I feel
resentful that was followed by an
extraordinary moment when he was taking
questions when a man with a heavily
Afrikaans accent asked a question and
identified himself as the chief
correspondent of the South African
Broadcasting Corporation Afrikaans
language service one of the voices of
apartheid and this man asked Mandela a
question Mandela said Yohan he
addressing him by his first name he said
I've been longing to meet you he said I
only had a radio for my last years in
prison you have been for me the voice of
South Africa you were the one on whom I
relied to learn what was going on in my
native country you did a wonderful job
you reported very fairly and I want to
thank you for that shook your hands had
Jill Hannah who had been shaking burst
into tears
so I was in the Johannesburg Bureau as
the number two correspondent from 1995
to 1999 when else in Mandela was
president and I never actually met
Nelson Mandela because that was the
village chief's job but towards the end
of my stint there he gave a speech at
the foreign correspondents Association
and normally I don't go buddy up to
important people but I thought people
were getting in line to meet him and I
thought oh come on Donald Oh be such a
prig this is Nelson Mandela its Madiba
he's a living Saint he's 80 years old
how much longer is he gonna be here go
up and shake his hand so I got in line
with everybody else and Mandela starts
to come down the line in shaking hands
in his shaking hands and I'm trying to
think of something to say and he gets
the person just am i right and then he
turns to face me and then he glances up
over my shoulder and he just glides
right past me and takes a hand of the
person next to me and you can hear him
say you must be a basketball player and
I turn and there's a stunningly
beautiful 6-foot two-inch woman in her
high-heeled standing next to me and
Mandela has blown right past me he's
holding her hand and she starts to
giggle and say oh no mister mmm mr.
president I don't play basketball I said
oh but you are an athlete aren't you and
she said well I swim a swimmer
oh that's wonderful and I thought well
you unrepentant old hound dog you know
who you are 80 years old and still at it
and so I never got to meet Nelson
Mandela although I got to see his his
charm up close
the first time that I met Nelson Mandela
in person I was going to his house to
meet with him late at night with the
executive editor of the New York Times
who was visiting South Africa and we
pulled up in front of this house which
was a very ordinary looking house and
suburbs outside of Johannesburg and
there wasn't even a lot of security I
think there was one guy standing in the
driveway and we I remember being shocked
by that and we walked up to the front
door and some young woman assured us and
everything was very dark you did get the
sense that he was alone in that house
and that in fact might be a very lonely
life that Nelson Mandela had but anyways
he he eventually comes down and we have
tea we're sitting in in the living room
and he is talking to Joe and I have to
say I was in awe it was kind of hard to
figure out what I was supposed to do and
the two men talked for a while and I in
Nelson Mandela never looked at me and
and it was a little formal and stiff and
and then at a certain point he gets this
sort of sly smile on his face because he
had an incredible sense of humor and he
leans over to Joe and he says to him
looking at me says in my day a man would
would be embarrassed to have a wife who
looked like that and in my day a man's
wife needed a little more meat on her
bones and that was the kind of sense of
humor that Mandela had he was a little
bit of a tease I remember at one point
he got very angry at an opposition
politician and he called him he said he
had a Mickey Mouse operation and the
opposition politician got very angry and
he said Mandela was goofy if he was
Mickey Mouse and Mandela was goofy and a
couple of weeks later Mandela was in the
hospital for some kind of test and the
politician was in the hospital for a
heart problem and so Mandela went to
meet him
and he comes around the curtain in the
in the hospital room and he says Mickey
Mouse it's goofy
so he had a very good sense of humor
my family moved to Kenya in 1980 when I
was four years old my mother is from
Ethiopia and my father's from the United
States from Minnesota in my elementary
school in Nairobi there were lots of
other kids like me cross-cultural
relationships every shade of black brown
yellow what-have-you and in school we
learned that there was this country
called South Africa and they had a
system called apartheid and families
like ours were forbidden we weren't
allowed to live together we weren't
allowed to be together
our parents would not be allowed to
marry but we also learned that there was
a man named Nelson Mandela who was
sitting in a prison in South Africa for
fighting against the system and his
dream was to create a country where
families like ours could be together and
family and people of all races could
live in harmony when I moved to South
Africa at the end of 2011 to be the
bureau chief in Johannesburg
I was surprised and delighted to find
that now there are many families like
mine black whites Indian and it
literally is a rainbow nation now people
do marry whoever they want
of course the legacy of long racial
separation is not something that's
erased overnight or even in 20 years but
Nelson Mandela's vision of a non-racial
South Africa is on display in shopping
malls in wedding chapels in schoolyards
everywhere you go and I think that's
going to be a lasting legacy for this
country that suffered under a really
brutal system of racial separation that
today today people can be together no
matter who they are
Mandela was not heard he was he was
invisible to anybody except his closest
family and they could relay messages
back one fascinating aspect of that
period was that the government was
desperate to defuse the power that he
had they wanted him out of prison they
didn't want him to be an emblem or a
symbol they wanted him to renounce
violence they wanted him to go into some
kind of strange residential arrangement
whereby he'd live in one of the so
called homelands and he consistently
said no and on one I remember one
occasion particularly early 1985 in the
Jabulani Stadium in Soweto
9,000 people and they were waiting for
word from Zinzi Mandela one of the
daughters who just come back from
visiting and she told them that her
father had made very clear to her in
their conversations that his freedom and
dares could not be separated he wouldn't
accept his freedom until his people were
also free in a democratic society
